Al Himen's house is just a block from the levee breach.
It's a large, one-story home that was once shaded by a graceful, wrap-around porch and a huge oak tree in the front yard.
The floodwaters ripped his house off its foundation and slammed it against a stand of trees, where it sat underwater for three weeks.
The water was up to--What?--six, seven feet in here, which covers pretty much everything you have, from dressers, furnitures, beds, pictures on the wall.
So pretty much everything's gone.
Today the inside of the house, where Himen lived with his wife and six-year-old son, looks like it was picked up and shaken to bits by an angry child.
Everything is shattered, covered with thick, dry mud and mold.
See these pictures?
The kids.
This is the kind of stuff that will kind of break your heart, that you can't replace--stuff you can't replace.
Himen, who's just shy of 60 years old and a lifelong New Orleanian, had some flood insurance and says he's wealthy enough to rebuild.
But it's not clear that he can.
The city might raze this part of Lakeview right next to the levee to build a flood buffer zone.
Then there's the question that haunts many in this city: Will the levees hold next time?

Even if the house is repairable and it doesn't have to be razed, by the time you've put all your effort into rebuilding--the levee's supposed to be repaired back up to a Category 3 strength, which is not going to help a whole lot.
If it breaks again, we'll be back in the same thing.
So Himen says he and his wife have decided to leave this neighborhood and New Orleans.
She definitely doesn't want to come back here because of the levee, and it makes you feel kind of like we've been violated.
Now my wife is talking about moving somewhere where the ground is high--you don't have to worry about floods; away from where you even have to evacuate.
Despite his losses, Himen says he's fortunate he can afford to make such a choice, something many in this devastated city can't do.
But he also says it doesn't bode well for New Orleans that people like him want to leave instead of rebuild.

With a portable generator to run their power tools, they're rebuilding and have already gutted the ground floor of their two-story brick house.
It's been stripped of every nail, every shred of Sheetrock and insulation and then cleaned.
And we actually did it all ourselves.

And we wouldn't leave until it was done.
Across this city, from the working-class Lower Ninth Ward to more upscale neighborhoods like Lakeview, gutting your house has become a sort of political statement.
It says, `We're here and we're staying, notwithstanding concerns about too little help from FEMA, the lack of an overall plan from the city and insecurity about the levees.'

And Decoration Day, the way you describe it is really the predecessor of our Memorial Day.
I can't prove it, but I'm pretty well convinced that's the case.
It's a traditional that's alive and well now, basically in the upland South, more or less from the Appalachians, west and southwest of the Ozarks, maybe even to northeast Texas and eastern Oklahoma.
And then it kind of fades out with the plains, you might say.
But it's alive and well, and we were astonished to discover this tradition.
I say we, my wife and I.
She and I did work on this together.
As a folklorist, you sometimes wonder: Have all the traditions in the world by now been documented?

Well, it turns out here's a big tradition that hundreds of thousands of people in America participate in, and the rest of us are clueless, and so we started visiting decorations and cemeteries in the rural South, and it was really a transforming experience.

Yet even today, when we saw President Obama speak at Arlington National Cemetery after laying a wreath for the - at the tomb of the unknowns, there were people in the cemetery placing roses on every grave.
That's right.
That's the personal side of all decorations, whether it's the old-fashioned Decoration Day or the post-Civil War Memorial Day.
At some level, it also has the personal relationship between the people above ground and the people below the ground.
Yet Decoration Day, the day you and you and your wife describe it, is, well, it sort of combines that and the family barbecue, too.
Well, that's right because you go through - well, you clean the cemetery first.
Then you decorate the graves.
And then you have essentially a religious service right there in the cemetery - preaching, gospel singing, prayers and so forth.
And then there's some communing, you know, individually talking with friends, relatives, and then you end with dinner on the ground.
And dinner on the ground in the context of a cemetery on Decoration Day is literally dinner on the grounds of the cemetery.
And people, very often, you'll go through the rural South, and you'll see a cemetery, and there'll be a pavilion.
And you'll wonder: Well, what's that pavilion for?
And you might think: Well, maybe that's in case it's raining when they bury somebody.
But it's also for the events like Decoration Day, where people gather in the cemetery and then commune together afterwards on dinner on the ground.
And this of course took on new resonance after the awful experience this country underwent in the Civil War.
Yeah, I think the Civil War got the whole country focused even more on their relationship to the people underground.
There were suddenly so many of them.

And there was a touching event that happened where the wife of the general who was the commanding general - this is after the war - of the Grand Army of the Republic - that was essentially the Union veterans - John Logan(ph), well, Mary Logan(ph) and some friends were touring in Virginia after the war.
And they were in Petersburg, Virginia, and were told they should see this beautiful church, Blandford Church, and they were going there, and to get there you have to go through the cemetery.

And she noticed all the graves that were people buried from the late war were decorated with flowers, and they had little miniature flags set in them for, in effect, for the lost cause, you know, commemorating their fighting for it, though they lost and died.
And she was deeply moved by this.
So she goes back to Washington.
The first thing she tells John Logan the story of what she saw, and he says: Wow, this is a great idea.
We'll have everybody do it.
So he sends out an executive order to all the men in the Grand Army of the Republic to go out and decorate the graves of their fellows who had been fallen in the late battles.
And they did, and that was the beginning of the modern, first Northern Memorial Day, but now, by now, national Memorial Day.
